content: It is the oauth entries but how do they get there? On Win10 all the smtp and imap entries are there but Win11 introduced the oauth entries. It's not a problem as all the passwords are on RasPi 5 Ubuntu 24.04 and Win10
creator: steve446

content:
oauth uses the password only for the initial authentication, and even then is it done on a web page and not saved. When the authentication completes successfully a (I think) 10 digit/character oAuth token issued and is then used between the authenticated device and the provider until such times as the provider either revokes it in which case you will be asked to re-authenticate, or it is replaced with a new token. Reissuing of tokens is done automatically under the hood and there is no user interaction.

It has nothing to do with windows 10 or 11 or Linux or anything operating system. It is all about the changing requirements for authentication imposed by mail providers. SO these days you see no passwords of any substance in Thunderbird. It simply does not know them or use them unless the authentication method is normal password and that is becoming the exception with mail providers. I still use it with GMX, But Outlook, Gmail, Yahoo and AOL all use oauth now
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
It looks like you copied some account information into the profile folder, as the profiles folder itself appears in your screenshot. Do you still have the old computer. Assuming windows, here are the steps: Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

If the old computer is no longer available, can you post a screenshot of the exported profile so someone here can advise on how best to transfer it? That will help. Thank you
creator: davidsk

content:
Klik na prvú správu, ktorú chcem odstrániť (označí sa modro) Stlačím klávesu CTRL a stále ju držím a postupne klikám na správy ktoré chcem odstrániť (všetky sa postupne označujú na modro). Pustím klávesu CTRL a správy ktoré chcem odstrániť zostávajú modré. Nakoniec stlačím klávesu DELETE a sú odstránené.

Pokiaľ v Thunderbirde odstránite e-mail, tak sa v skutočnosti iba označí ako odstránený, ale fyzicky zostane. Jeho fyzické odstránenie sa vykoná až použitím voľby "Údržba priečinkov“. Takže aby ste zmenšili veľkosť priečinka je nutné ešte vykonať "Údržbu priečinkov": https://support.mozilla.org/cs/kb/provedeni-udrzby-slozek. POSTUP: - Thunderbird - Súbor - Vykonať údržbu priečinkov http://imgbank.cz/images/2015/08/19/Thunderbird_udrzba_priecinkov.jpg

content:
Generally when this occurs it is because the domain used to send the mails does not have the correct settings in DNS for DMARC and SPF. Those things are in no way related to Thunderbird, but I have seen a lot of folk that have hosted domains that do not have the email validations required by most major providers configured in DNS.

I suggest you try putting your email domain name into this web site for some basic checking of it's setup. https://intodns.com/

You might also want to check it here https://check.spamhaus.org/ as this is a major spam blacklisting site. It might give clues if your domain is on a shared host with spammers and therefore your domains email reputation is rubbish, or it could be your sending of bulk mails has seen your domain declared a spammer. The USA in particular has some very lax rules about unsolicited email (SPAM)which when companies in the USA start emailing outside the USA can get them in trouble rather quickly. For instance in my jurisdiction unless a company can prove they have permission to send commercial email to an address (like I emailed you requesting something or subscribed to say a special offers newsletter) the corporate fines are huge (put you out of business huge). See https://www.acma.gov.au/avoid-sending-spam

One thing I am not going to say is that is is the gmail host in the middle that is the deifinate cause of your troubles. If you are using the domains SMTP server instead of the gmail server then it is actually most unlikely to be the problem. Do not get me wrong, it might be the way you have set up Thunderbird. But from what you are said it does not sound like it. Hence the other suggestions in the first instance.

I do not know and neither does anyone else if you do not know it. Only the person who set it will even know it.

See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/protect-your-thunderbird-passwords-primary-password

If you mean your mail account password, rather than a Thunderbird primary password, you will need to consult your email account provider. Thunderbird generally stores passwords in the password manager, but it does not set them and it does not store them for oAuth authenticated mail accounts at all. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb

content:
Because I have set up two Accounts, I have three "Sent" folders: one under each Account, plus one under "Local Folders." I have edited my accounts so that all sent emails are copied to the same "Sent" Folder. The process i used to do that was: 1. From the main menu, select Edit > Account Settings 2. For each Account:

  • Select "Copies & Folders"
  • Ensure that the "Place a copy in:" box is checked
  • Click on the destination field after "'Sent' folder on:"
  • Select my preferred location for Sent emails.

content:
OK; partly resolved!

Almost as soon as I posted the above a whole bunch of similar questions appeared in the right hand margin. I followed some of the responses and was able to determine that the two apps, Outlook and Thunderbird, needed to have the same bit width. I fully uninstalled Thunderbird and reinstalled the 32-bit version. Now the import feature works.

Now I need to re-install a second time and reset the server settings on Thunderbird to SMTP/POP3. I had completed the import process with Outlook set up as SMTP/POP3, and Thunderbird set up as SMTP/IMAP so I inadvertently uploaded all my emails back to my ISP's mail servers.

More to come...
creator: Old-Newby

Puoi spiegare meglio? Come procedi? Cosa non funziona? Inoltre, Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird

  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

1) Versione di Thunderbird 140.2.0ESR (64 bit) 2) Versione del sistema operativo WINDOWS 11 HOME VERSIONE 24H2 3) Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.) UTILIZZO UN PROVIDER LOCALE TEXNET, ARUBA, LIBERO E LA PEC CON ARUBA 4) Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP) TEXNET È POP3, GLI ALTRI IMAP 5) Estensioni installate GOOGLE CALENDAR, MA È DISATTIVATO 6) Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird NESSUN MESSAGGIO DI ERRORE, SEMBRA SALVARE IL FILE REGOLARMENTE 7) Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili) ANTIVIRUS MCAFEE, SEMPRE AVUTO. 8) Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto) PURTROPPO NON C'È NIENTE PER FARE UNO SCREENSHOT.

L'unica cosa che può essere successa nel fine settimana, è un aggiornamento di windows di cui allego lo screenshot. Potrebbe esserne la causa??

Grazie per l'assistenza. Saluti Stefano

Check Settings > Config Editor > mail.serverDefaultStoreContractID ... set it to 1 and restart.

content:
They are not actually, physically linked. They just have information in their headers that indicate that they are part of a series of responses to a thread. Thunderbird can view them as a "Conversation" in a tree format or not. You can view your message list in either Convesation/theaded mode or non-threaded, which I think is what you're looking for.

One of the icons in the Message List columns header lets you toggle between modes. Attached are two screen clips showing a threaded vs and unthreaded view and the icon to switch between views. (I hope your layout is similar enough to mine that you can find the toggle.)
creator: rednoise
